text: The wind finally stopped. The snow stopped as well. Outside the North Gate, only the crackling of dying embers remained, along with the soldiers’ disbelieving breaths.
The barrier’s blue light no longer collapsed. Like a string pulled taut again, it held steady around the outer wall.
The black mist left behind by the Demon King was scattered by the wind, revealing blasted snow and shattered stone—like a nightmare torn into pieces.
I knelt in the snow, my hands still trembling. My fingertips touched something warm—not fire, but her body heat.
Alicia lay in his arms, her armor shattered halfway through, her silver hair damp with snow. Her eyes were closed, but she was still breathing.
The breathing was shallow, but not the kind that meant ‘she’s leaving’—it was more like someone who had finally allowed herself to sleep.
“Alicia…?”
Her eyelashes trembled slightly, as if confirming that what she heard wasn’t an illusion.
“I heard it.”
“Heard what?”
“You said you’d wait for me.”
She tried to lift her hand, her fingertips brushing his sleeve, like grabbing hold of a line that could pull her back.
“This time… I wasn’t alone.”
Someone ran over, cloak whipping up snow.
Lucia rushed forward. When she saw Alicia still alive, all the strength seemed to drain from her, and she nearly collapsed to her knees.
“Mentor… you’re still here… you’re really still here…”
Alicia struggled to glance at her, her voice hoarse but clear:
“This time, don’t cry.”
Lucia nodded hard, but tears still pattered into the snow.
Battle mages rushed in to check the barrier, confirming that the rift was closing. Someone shouted “We did it!”, the sound carrying across the wall.
The soldiers didn’t cheer. They just stood there, as if they could finally lower their lives from their throats.
I held Alicia a little tighter, as if loosening my grip would let time steal her away again.
“Let’s go home.”
She froze for a moment, as if the word ‘home’ had never belonged to her.
“…Okay.”
They walked back toward the town along the snowy road. A pale golden line began to appear on the horizon, as if dawn were being gently pried open.
People peeked out from the streets, doors opening a crack as they confirmed the monsters were truly gone.
As they passed the fountain square, a child ran up clutching a bag of freshly baked bread, panting, and shoved it into Alicia’s arms.
The child looked up at her, eyes shining like stars:
“Big sister, you’re amazing! I want to be like you someday!”
Alicia looked down at the steaming bag of bread, her fingers slowly tightening.
Her lips twitched, as if she wanted to smile but feared it would shatter if she did. In the end, she smiled anyway—for the first time, a real smile.
“Then the first thing you need to learn—don’t overdo it.”
I glanced at her sideways, as if seeing someone who had finally stepped out of the snow.
The tavern door was pushed open. The hearth fire was still burning. The familiar scent of wood rushed out to meet us.
This time, there was no crushing sense of countdown, no feeling of ‘next time.’ Only real exhaustion, and real warmth.
I set her down on a chair and hurried to fetch hot water and clean cloth.
Lucia helped in a fluster, muttering nonstop about how she could possibly push herself that hard.
“Mentor, if you ever rush out alone again—I’m really going to be angry!”
Alicia closed her eyes and gave a soft “mm,” like she was admitting fault.
As I bandaged her, my fingers brushed the circular mark below her heart. It no longer darkened, no longer burned.
It seemed to have finally lost its grip on time, quietly fading away.
“Is it… really over?”
She opened her eyes and slowly nodded.
“It’s over.”
She paused, as if finally setting down a weight she’d carried hundreds of times.
“I don’t have to go back to three days ago anymore.”
“And I don’t have to pretend it’s the first time I’ve met you.”
The room fell silent for a few seconds. The fire popped softly, as if bearing witness for them.
“Then what now?”
Alicia looked at him. The bloodshot lines in her eyes were still there, but the manic brightness was gone. In its place was something long-lost and warm.
“Now—I want to learn how to live.”
“Not the kind of life that saves the world.”
“The kind where I can space out, eat meals, and get scolded by you for making the soup too salty.”
I laughed out loud, my eyes burning red: “If you dare put the salt back on the left side again—I’ll really complain.”
She laughed too, softly—yet it felt like it melted the entire winter just a little.
Lucia sniffed beside them, then suddenly put on a stern face on purpose.
“What about me? Don’t I get a part too?”
Alicia reached out and ruffled her hair, the motion awkward but sincere:
“Of course you do. From now on… we do it together.”
Late into the night, the tavern lights were not extinguished as early as usual.
They finished eating bread that had gone cold, and drank wine that should have been sold long ago.
No one mentioned ‘the loop.’ No one mentioned ‘next time.’
Because this time, time itself was finally willing to move forward.
I placed the brass dice back into the deepest drawer of the counter and closed it.
The dice no longer rolled. It lay still, like an ordinary piece of metal.
Outside the window, the snow fell softly, like a blessing.
Alicia leaned back in the chair, eyes half-closed, her voice drowsy and soft:
“Tomorrow… I want to try being the boss lady.”
“Are you sure? You’ll scare the customers away.”
“Then I’ll keep just one customer.”
She fell asleep right after saying that, her forehead gently resting against the table, finally safe.
I didn’t move. I stayed beside her and pulled her cloak over her.
The firelight reflected on her face—no longer like snow, no longer like a blade.
Like home.
